titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI: Monday. I had a morning quiet and uninterrupted; the first since we landed at New-York— It was occupied in writing and continuing the examination of my brother’s accounts. I went with my wife and my Son George and dined at Mr William Foster’s, at Boston— A small family party. W. Foster junr. and his daughter Virginia—Charles Foster and his wife—H. G. Otis, Coll: and Mrs Apthorp, who was Mary Foster, and Mr Holley formed the party— We left George in town to go to Cambridge and enter upon his studies to-morrow. Returned with my wife to Quincy, this Evening.

2. V:15. After an early breakfast I went to my brother’s and made some progress towards the settlement of his accounts with me. Returned at eleven to my father’s, and met De Grand, who had come from Boston to see me. Had much and various conversation with him. Dined with my wife and my father, mother & Louisa Smith, at Mr Barney Smith’s on Milton Hill. The house built by Governor Hutchinson, where General James Warren once lived, and after him P. Jeffrey. Judge Davis, G. Blake, Dr Coney, Mr Holley, and several others with my brother and his wife, were of the Company. We came away at the dusk of Evening, and went to a party at Mr J. Marston’s in Quincy. Home between nine and ten.

3. V:15. Went to Cambridge with my wife and Lucy; found George at Mrs Gilman’s. He went to Cambridge yesterday . . . called at Mr Gilman the tutor’s chamber in Holworthy Hall, with George. His terms are two dollars a week, and he is to give him instruction, in all the objects of study which may qualify him to enter the University as a Sophomore after the winter vacation; but he intimated that it would be difficult, and would require very close application from George— We proceeded to Boston, and I stopp’d at the Post Office, where I met Mr Cruft. Mr Hill, the Post Master was not there— I left the Packages of Mr Bentham’s and Mr Owen’s books and pamphlets addressed to the Governor’s of the several States, to be forwarded. My wife went to Mr James H. Foster’s. Mr Cruft went with me to the Custom House— The Collector-General Dearborn junr. was not there— The Deputy Collector Mrand the naval Officer Mr Melvill, to whom I shewed the list of trunks and packages which I left with Coll. Aspinwall to be shipp’d for Boston, assured me that the order for their delivery free of examination or duty should be given immediately upon their arrival. I gave the list to Mr Cruft. I expect them to come by the Galen.
I next went to the Office of Messrs. Payne and Co. brokers in State-Street. Joseph Hall junr. son of my old friend is Payne’s partner— I left with them three West-Boston Bridge Shares for sale; being in immediate want of the money, I desired they should be sold immediately for what they would fetch; but I had carelessly neglected to ascertain by my brother’s accounts, what income they had yielded during my absence— I also left an order with Payne and Co. to purchase for me any Middlesex Canal shares that may be in the market at 250 dollars a share, besides the last Assessment of 80 dollars now payable— I executed the transfer of the Bridge Shares in blank at Mr Stevenson the Notary’s office, and on going out I met Jo. Hall and went with him to the Athenaeum after stopping to view H. Sargent’s picture of Christ entering into Jerusalem. Between two and three I went to Mr James H. Foster, where I received notes from Payne and Co. and from Commodore Bainbridge. The former to say they had an offer of 240. dollars a share for the West Boston Bridge Stock: had purchased 5 shares of the Middlesex Canal at 250 dollars each the last Assessment to be paid by me, and were waiting for my orders. I answered desiring them to close the bargain for the bridge shares. Bainbridge’s Letter was to invite me to go on board the Independence 74 to-morrow Morning; I answered him that I would be ready at ten O’Clock. We dined at H. G. Otis’s with a party of twenty-five, among whom Israel Thorndike, Coll. & Mrs Morris and their daughter, Coll. and Mrs Murray, Coll. and Mrs Apthorp, W. Lyman and his wife, H. G. Otis junr. and wife, and Dr. and Mrs Warren— I made further enquiries about the town school and the teacher Mr Gould, Mr and Mrs Otis both strongly recommended them. Mr I. Thorndike told me that since the immense advantage of the possession of Louisiana to this Country was ascertained, he thought the Florida’s ought to be acquired, at any expence. From Otis’s we called at W. Foster junr. to see his wife, but she was not visible. I spent the Evening with the old Wednesday Evening’s club at Judge Davis’s. We lodge at Mr James H. Foster’s.

4. V:15.Judge Davis came at half past seven this Morning; we called at Mr Gray’s, where we found W. S. Shaw who with F. C. Gray went with us to the Linnaean Society Rooms at the Boylston Market Hall. They have there an incipient collection of natural history—Birds, Beasts, Fishes, insects and shells. We saw the skin of the Sun fish caught a few days since in Boston Harbour, and which weighed 150 pounds—A Sun fish. I recommended to Judge Davis who is President of the Linnaean Society to enter into correspondence with the Botanical Society at Ghent; and am to give him the name of its Secretary— I called at A. H. Everett’s house and office, without finding him— Then went to Payne and Co.’s and finished the business of the Bridge Stock— They agreed to take of me 100 shares of U.S. Bank Stock at 191. dollars a share, and declined taking more. I opened an account with the U.S. Branch Bank; made a deposit there, and took an order upon the Branch at New-York, in favour of J. P. De Wint to repay the money that I borrowed of him at New-York— At half past ten I went with my wife and Mr James H. Foster and his wife to the long wharf where we found a boat ready, and went on board the Ship Independence— A Salute of 13 guns was fired at our going on board, and a tour departure: The yards were manned, and the marines drawn up on deck to receive us, under arms. Commodore Bainbridge shewed us every part of the ship—everything was in perfect order. The crew were ranged in line upon the Cabin deck as we passed; and at a signal crossed from the Starboard to the Larboard side almost instantaneously. Bainbridge introduced all his Lieutenants to us. We returned to Boston and immediately came out to my father’s. We dined with his and my brothers families at Quincy’s. Mrs Storer & Mrs Morton, Mr Whitney and Mr Coleman, a Dr. Goff of Charleston South Carolina, F. C. Gray, and W. S. Shaw were there— The day was excessively warm. We came home after dark. F. C. Gray gave me a Letter enclosing Bank Bills, which he thinks he owes me.

5. IV:30. I took with my Son John a Sea Bath this Morning at Mrs Black’s Wharf— Answered F. C. Gray’s Letter and declined accepting his Bills. A Mrs Pritchard came out last Evening from Boston, about a mortgage upon a house of Peter Osgood’s, which my brother took for a debt of 1000 dollars to me. She is mother in Law to Osgood, and has a subsequent mortgage on the same Estate— She asked me to call upon Mr A. Ward in Boston and a Mr Asa Richardson who she said was ready to pay the money for her and take an assignment of my mortgage— I promised to call on them to-morrow. Dr Waterhouse came from Cambridge to see me, and went with us all, and dined at my brother’s. Captain Beale and his Son George. T. Greenleaf and his two Sons. D. Greenleaf and Mr Marston were of the company. After dinner I rode with my wife and my father down to view the Mount Wollaston farm— At dusk we returned home to a large evening party at my Mother’s; about sixty persons— Mr John Bailey the applicant for the Office of first Clerk in the Department of State came and called me out from the company, to present me two more letters urgently recommending him; from judge Story and from Genl. Dearborn. Mr Marston likewise recommended him with great earnestness. This mode of solicitation accords neither with my feelings, nor with my sense of propriety. Mr G. A. Otis also, who was of the Evening party, requested me to give him a private interview to-morrow morning, to which I agreed— Bailey told me that he desired the Office which he solicits very ardently.

6. V:Dr Waterhouse yesterday while here alarmed my wife and Mother, about the state of the health of the People in Cambridge, where a malignant dysentery combined with a typhus fever is raging, and has in many cases been fatal, among them are two of professor Hedge’s children, and two young Foster’s, sons of Bossenger Foster, and who were on the point of marriage with the two younger daughters of the late judge Dana. My Mother last Evening advised me to take George from Cambridge until the prevalence of this infectious disease shall have passed off. I Bathed with my sons John and Charles and my brother’sson Thomas at Mrs Black’s wharf. After breakfast I went into Boston alone. Called at Mr W. Gray’s, and left an Answer for his Son Francis— Neither of them was at home. Stopp’d at James H. Foster’s shop. I had authorised him to sell my Neponset Bridge Shares at 530 dollars a share, but now withdrew the authority— I found on examining my brother’s accounts that my West-Boston Shares had yielded on the average an income of 20 dollars yearly, and that they were worth one third more than what they sold for. This was a lesson for my carelessness and precipitation. I called at the Athenaeum, but Shaw was not there— I left for Mr Charles Bulfinch some papers which he had put into my hands, the day before yesterday relating to a certain claim of land upon the North West Coast of America, which he and others have, and concerning which they have received enquiries from the Department of State. Went to Dr Welsh’s. On the way and there, I received several Letters; and a parcel of pamphlets from Dr Morse of Charlestown— Mrs Welsh agreed to take my Sons John and Charles to board and lodge, and they are to attend the Town Grammar School— Going from Dr Welsh’s into State Street I met Judge Dawes who invited me to dine with him. I called at Payne and Co.’s— The day before yesterday just before leaving town I had received a Note from them, saying they believed they could dispose of from 50 to 100 shares more of my U.S. Bank Shares at $151. a share and they would charge me 1/4 per Cent brokerage. I answered their Note, authorising them to make the sale and agreeing to pay the brokerage. This Morning the Newspapers quote the same Bank Shares both at Philadelphia and New-York at 156. and when I entered their office they put into my hand a Letter from themselves, of this morning stating that they had disposed of all my remaining Shares, 250 at $151 a share— I observed to them that their Note of Thursday, and my answer to it had reference only to, from 50 to 100 Shares. That I could not now wish to dispose of more at that rate, when the price both at New-York and Philadelphia was so much higher— I would certainly not retract from the authority of my own Note, but should expect the money to be deposited in Bank this day or before I leave town for Washington, and did not wish to sell any more shares than I had expressly authorised them to sell. Payne said that perhaps the Gentleman who had agreed to take them would release the bargain for all the shares, excepting those of which the transfer was executed. I said I should be much obliged to him if he would. Half an hour after they informed me that he had agreed to release the whole; and that they had deposited in the Branch Bank the Money for the hundred shares sold, deducting the amount paid for the five Middlesex Canal Shares— I went to Mr A. Ward’s Office. He sent for the Mr Richardson, mentioned by Mrs Pritchard, and he paid me the money due on Osgood’s Note— There was some question as to the amount of the interest due; but I returned after dinner to Mr Ward’s Office, where Richardson paid the balance for interest, and I assigned the Mortgage to him, and endorsed the Note— I deposited the 1000 dollars in the Branch Bank. Dined at Judge Dawes’s. Dr Freeman, Mr Holley and two Appleton’s were there— Only one of Dawes’s children: a daughter present— I had called and excused myself from dining at Dr Welsh’s, and while I was at the house Mr T. Lyman called and paid me a visit. Harriet Welsh goes with us to New-York but I have been obliged to postpone our departure from Monday to Wednesday Morning— Dawes’s dinner was pleasant as possible, and short. Between 4 and 5. I left his house, and was going towards Cambridge when I met George in the Street, and took him with me. On the Cambridge Common we met and spoke to Dr Waterhouse who approved of George’s leaving the town while the distemper is so virulent. We went to Mrs Gilman’s to give her notice, and take his books. She approved of the measure herself. We got home to my fathers house about eight in the Evening.

7. V: Heard Mr Whitney this Morning from Hebrews XI.1. “Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen;” and after dinner from Revelations XXI.27. [“]And there shall in no wise enter into it any thing that
defileth, neither whatsoever worketh abomination, or maketh a lie; but they which are written in the Lamb’s book of life.”— Mr and Mrs T. Tarbell came and dined with us at my father’s. I had hoped to have some time this afternoon for writing, but immediately after meeting my Mother invited my wife and me to take a ride with her to Bent’s point, where the new Bridge is, and where all the improvements of Quincy during our absence have been made. We had not returned more than a quarter of an hour when I was called from the Office to a visit from Ernestus Plummer and Mr Loud, from Dorchester; and from that time a succession of evening visitors till ten O’Clock— The circle was renewed three times, and my father has these companies of the Ladies and Gentlemen of Quincy, every Sunday Evening.

8. V: I wrote this Morning with less than usual interruption till breakfast time; and nearly recovered my journalizing arrears. I then walked across the fields to my brother’s house, and settled my accounts with him to this day— It was a laborious occupation for the morning; and from this time the accounts are to commence anew— I walked home, and we dined at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s. The Ladies, and my brother’s wife dined at home. The party at Mr Greenleaf’s was small. Dr Goff of S. Carolina was among them. After dinner we were called home by visitors from Boston and of Quincy, General Miller, and Mr and Mrs W. Foster junr.Mr Buzzy, Mr Marston and his daughters,Mr and Mrs. John Greenleaf, and many others, until nine or ten in the Evening— This was the day upon which I had fixed for our departure from Boston; but I have been obliged to postpone it till Wednesday. Among the visitors this afternoon was John Welsh, and his Sister Harriet who is going with us to New-York.

9. V: Left Quincy for Washington— Wrote Letters to J. P. De Wint, R. Rush, Dr Morse, and H. Mann. The boys John and Charles obtained permission, to stay at Quincy till Thursday, when they are to go to Boston, to reside at Dr Welsh’s and to attend the town Grammar School. George remains at Quincy till the Epidemick at Cambridge shall have subsided. I came with my wife and Lucy to Boston. We dined and lodge at James H. Foster’s. I called at Dr Welsh’s at the Loan Office where I saw B. Austin the Collector and met my Classmate Rand; at the U.S. Branch Bank where I had some conversation with W. Gray— Met Judge Davis and gave him Cornelissen’s Bouquet. He promised that the Linnaean Society would commence a correspondence with the botanical Society at Ghent. After dinner I went to the Grammar School, saw Mr Gould and gave him such information relating to my Sons John & Charles, as will enable him to give the proper direction to their Studies— Visited with my wife at B. Pickman junr: & Mr Cruft’s, but found nobody at home— My wife then paid other visits, and I went to the Athenaeum. Wrote to my brother & to my Son George. Evening at Mr Foster’s where we had visits from G. Blake—De Grand, Dr Ingalls, and F. Gray. I received this day a Letter from J. Marston of Quincy who had recommended his friend Bailey for the Office of first Clerk in the Department of State— He now recommends himself for the same place— I engaged four Seats in the Stage for Providence that is to go at noon to-morrow.

10. V: Providence. I finished this morning the remainder of business on hand, and wrote Letters to J. Marston, and to Cornelissen. Called at A. H. Everett’s house in Franklin Place. He is gone with his wife to Portland. At W. Sullivan’s Office to enquire for his brother John— Gone to Portsmouth— At the Bank—finished my business there. At Dr Welsh’s and took leave. De Grand called just as we were departing. At Noon the Stage came for us, having already taken up Harriet Welsh. There were five Gentlemen Passengers besides. We dined at Dedham, and arrived at Chappotin’s, Providence at half-past seven. We found here Mr Henry Fearon, who arrived yesterday from New-York and is proceeding to Boston. He is not pleased with New-York, and has given up his project of settling in this Country— My wife found the motion of the Stage too violent and rapid, and arrived at Providence unwell. Instead therefore of waiting for the Mail Stage from Boston to-morrow, which arrives here between ten and eleven I engaged an extra-Stage to go at seven in the Morning— Mr Artiguenave came to me this morning and read me an extract of a Letter that he had received from Mr Gilles at Philadelphia, a French Musician proposing to him a plan for opening a school of music and declamation, and of the French and Spanish languages, and to apply to the Government of the United States, for funds to support the establishment, as the Conservatoire des Arts is supported at the expence of the French Government— I told him that would be out of the question here. The Government took no part or concern in such things— But as a private undertaking such a plan might perhaps succeed in New-York or Philadelphia.

11. V. New London— We left Chappotin’s in our Extra-Stage at eight O’Clock this Morning and arrived the same hour of the Evening at Shepard’s Hotel, New London. The Stages are to Scituate 15. Plainfield 15. Norwich 14 and New London sixteen Miles. We should have changed horses at every Stage; but there were none at Scituate, and we went to Plainfield with the same team. There we dined in company with three Gentlemen who were going the way whence we came. The heat great part of the day was excessive, and the dust greatly annoyed us. The road is over hills and rocks
the whole way but a turnpike, kept in good order. The first town in Connecticut is Plainfield, and from thence the face of the Country is more pleasant with occasional intervals between the rocks. I was musing the greater part of this day.— As the Evening came on there was a change from the scorching heat of the Sun to coolness which again affected my wife so much that she arrived at New London very ill; with a high fever, a violent ague in the face, and fainting. She was obliged to retire immediately to bed.

12. V:30.My wife had a very bad night, and mine was not much better. She was however much recovered this morning, and after breakfasting at Shepard’s we embarked in the Steam-Boat Fulton, Captain Law, at the wharf immediately behind the Hotel, and as the Clock was striking eight the Boat was loosened from the wharf. All the Morning the Sun was intensely hot, and not a breath of wind was stirring. The tide from eleven to five was against us; yet we arrived at New-Haven, a distance of sixty Miles, at seven in the Evening. There was a thunder-shower from three to six in the afternoon. We had about thirty fellow passengers, one of whom had travelled with us from Boston to Providence. The rest were all strangers to us, chiefly Virginians and South-Carolinians. The dinner was sumptuous, and well served. It was low water when we arrived at New-Haven, and it was with difficulty we reached the wharf— There was some wrangling political discourse after dinner between a Mr George Edwards of Charleston South-Carolina, and two or three New-England men— Edwards severely, and in very coarse language reprobated the conduct of New-England during the late War. Law told me that they consumed about five Cords of pine wood in his boat for each of their passages. I wrote a few lines to Ellen Nicholas, which Harriet Welsh copied for me, and I read a manuscript life of Van der Kemp, which she lent me; written by himself, and addressed to his son— The Steam-Boat Connecticut, Captain Bunker, arrived at the wharf at New-Haven an hour after us. She grounded once or twice in coming up— We passed directly from one boat to the other, and at Nine in the Evening were again loose from the wharf, and on our way to New-York. Mr Boyd, formerly of Portsmouth—an old acquaintance of mine, passed from the Connecticut into the Fulton; he recognized and spoke to me; and said he had been several years residing in New-Orleans, and was now going to visit his friends at Portsmouth. We were not over crowded with passengers in the Fulton; but the day before yesterday had been commencement day at New-Haven; and there were multitudes of people from New-York, who had been to attend it, and were now returning home. There were thus one hundred and forty or fifty passengers, with accommodations for about sixty. It became necessary therefore, both for the Ladies and Gentlemen to draw lots for the births, an arrangement to which some objected, but which ultimately prevailed— I drew three tickets for my wife, Harriet Welsh, and Lucy, and among them found two numbers and one blank. Captain Bunker however instead of giving me a ticket, said he could not go to bed, and gave me one of the births in his own Cabin. It was so dark that we could not distinguish the faces of our new fellow passengers; but a gentleman without naming himself entered much into conversation with me, upon the projected plan for sending a Colony of Free People of Colour to Africa; gave me a pamphlet containing the proceedings at Washington, upon the subject, and said he had been himself applied to to go upon a mission connected with the plan— I retired to bed about midnight, before which a fresh breeze from the Northward arose, and there was a great and sudden transition, from sultry heat to coldness for a cloak—

13. V: We had both wind and tide in our favour the greatest part of the Night, and had the benefit of a large square sail, as well as of the Steam-Engine— We passed through Hell-gate, imperceptibly to almost all our passengers, and at half past six this Morning landed at New-York, at the wharf, at the bottom of Fulton-Street. We took our lodgings at Mrs Moore’s N. 53. Dey. Street, which my wife preferred to Mrs Bradish’s, as being less crowded with Company. After breakfast I called upon Mr Trumbull, and saw his first chalking out of his great Picture of the Declaration of Independence. He went with me to the exhibition at the Academy of Arts, but he said he was thoroughly ashamed of it, and he had reason to be so. It was very bad, and indicated a state of the Arts worse than any idea I had before entertained of it. Mr M’Cormick called upon us twice and invited us to dine with him to-morrow. W. S. Clarkson also came to see us after dinner. Harriet Welsh took passage in the Steam-Boat
Richmond, going up the North-river. She was going to Mr De Wint’s at Cedar-grove, Fishkill landing 65 miles from New-York. We accompanied her to the Boat, which left the wharf at five O’Clock, and was to reach Newburg opposite Fishkill about twelve at Night. Coll. Trumbull called to see us this Evening. Being much wearied by the loss of rest, great part of the two preceding Nights, we retired between eight and nine.

14. V:15. As we were at Breakfast this Morning J. P. De Wint came in; he had come down the river last Night, on purpose to meet Harriet Welsh here, and return with her to Cedar Grove. Harriet went under the charge of Mr Ten Broek, a clergyman who lives at Fishkill, and an acquaintance of Clarkson’s and the De Wint’s who was returning home. Clarkson came and attended me to Trinity Church, where we heard Bishop Hobart, preach from Psalm XCVII:2. “Clouds and darkness are round about him: righteousness and judgment are the habitation of his throne,” one of the best Sermons I have heard for many years. I observed the variations from the mode of service as practiced in England, which are very inconsiderable. The most important is the Omission from the Prayer-Book, of the Athanasian Creed, and a corresponding alteration of the Article of the Church sanctioning the Creeds. The Apostles and Nicene Creeds being retained. There is some variation in the phraseology of the Collects, and some option left to the Ministers to read or omit certain parts of the Litany. The Bishop read the whole service himself; and the portion of the Communion service, which is read every Sunday, at the desk before the pulpit, with the rest, and without going to the Communion table— He announced that the Sacrament would be administered next Sunday, and read from the Prayer-Book an earnest exhortation to receive it— After Church I went to the Battery, and on Board of the Steam-Boat in which we are to embark to-morrow Morning— Thence returned home, and received the visit of Coll. and Mrs. Trumbull. I went to Shiels at his painting room N. 20. Wall-Street, and sat to him an hour to finish my picture. He says he has not been an hour disengaged since he arrived in New-York: that he has more work than he can do, and has now more than fifty orders for Portraits upon hand— Our fellow passenger of the Steerage Davis came in while I was there. He is engaged as a Printer of Stereotype Bibles; and also as an Instrumental Musician at the Theatre: well satisfied with his success here; and intending to send for the rest of his family to come to him— I Dined with my wife and W. S. Clarkson at M’Cormick’s. De Wint came in after dinner, and we all sat at table till eight O’Clock.

15. V:15. Precisely at seven O’Clock this Morning, we embarked in the Steam-Boat Olive-Branch, Captain Moore; and at half-past twelve, reached Brunswick; the distance 45 miles. We breakfasted before leaving New-York; and again in the boat. Dined at the Tavern, where we landed from the Boat at Brunswick: then proceeded in Stages, over the Turnpike road to Princeton 16. and to Trenton 11. Miles. We arrived before six in the Evening at Trenton, and lodge at a new tavern, connected with the Steam-Boat-line; on the bank of the river— We were seven passengers in the Stage N. 3. in which we came. In each of the two other Stages there were ten passengers; but they neither stopped at the landing place at Brunswick to dine nor came to lodge at the same house with us at Trenton. The weather all the Morning was cold and cheerless; and there was a heavy rain all the time we were in the Stages and all the Evening. We found a fire at the Inn at Trenton. My wife, arrived very ill; unable to bear the jolting of the Stages and the roughness of the roads. She retired immediately to bed. I had neglected to change my Summer garments for warmer cloathing, and was visited with a severe attack of rheumatism in the thighs. Among our fellow passengers is a Mr Burrell of Baltimore whom I find a very social and pleasant companion.

16. V. After suffering great part of the Night with my rheumatism, I found myself towards Morning entirely relieved, my wife was also quite recovered. At six this Morning we embarked in the Steam-Boat Philadelphia, Captain Jenkins in which we came to Philadelphia. The distance on the river is 36 Miles, though by land only 30. They stopped at Bordentown, Bristol and Burlington to take in and land way-passengers— We breakfasted in the boat, and landed at Philadelphia just before eleven. We found in the boat most of the passengers who had been with us yesterday, and many others, among whom a Quaker named Coates and his wife and, a young man named Craig who was at St. Petersburg in 1811, with Dr. Griffith. We came to lodge at the Mansion House in South third Street, now called the Washington Hotel, and kept by Renshaw. After dressing I called upon my old friend Saml. Ewing whom I found with a family of four children. I put into his hands the papers of Mr Jump and Mr K[oe], and left him to determine whether he can undertake the object for which they were sent here. He went with me, first to the U.S. Bank where the papers which I had expected have not been received, and where I saw the Cashier Mr Smith, and Charles Nicholas who is a clerk in the transfer Office— I next went with him to W. Meredith’s and found him at home. I called at Delaplaine’s gallery and afterwards met him in the Street. Gave him a verbal answer to the Letter I had received from him in London, and had some conversation with him concerning a Letter which he lately wrote to W. S. Shaw, asking for a biographical memoir of my father, and for the loan of a portrait
of him to be engraved for Delaplaine’s collection. I kept Ewing until he lost his dinner at home, but he declined coming to dine with us at the Hotel. We dined at four in our chamber, and after dinner Ewing came in; and also Mr Correa de Serra the Portuguese Minister, who spent an hour with us, and whose conversation we found intelligent and agreeable. I paid with my wife a short Evening visit to Mrs Rush, and returned before Nine. Mr and Mrs Meredith and their daughter came to visit us, after we had retired for the Night.

17. V: I went to the U.S. Bank and transacted as much of my business as could be accomplished at this time. Then called upon Mr John Vaughan, who had been yesterday at the Hotel to visit us. On returning, I found that W. Meredith had been again here this Morning. We had visits from Mrs and Miss Rush, from Mr Pedersen the Danish Minister; from J. Connell, J. Sargent, Rawle, Dr Chapman, Mr Hazlehurst, Mr Biddle, and many others. Ewing came and accompanied me to the Academy of Arts, where the Collection of picture’s is much superior to that of New-York— I dined by invitation with a party of twelve friends. Ewing, Meredith, J. Sargent, Dr Chapman, General Cadwalader, Biddle, Nicholas, Rawle junr.Charles Hare, Markoe, Hallowell, and Joseph Ingersoll— In the Evening I passed an hour with my wife at Mrs. Rush’s, where we met her two youngest sons, Mrs and Miss Dallas, and Mr and Mrs Bache. We came home before tea.

18. V:30. Newcastle— I was much engaged all the morning until the time for our departure from Philadelphia. Wrote Letters to my brother and to Payne and Co. at Boston, the latter of which however I did not send. I went to the U.S. Bank, with J. Connell, who introduced me there to the President W. Jones. I found that my Certificate of Shares, though not at the Bank, was in the hands of brokers in the City— Connell went also with me to the Office of the Schuylkill permanent Bridge Company, where I received two dividends; and to the United States Mint where I saw Mr Patterson the President. He agreed to take my Dutch Ducats, and coin them over into half-eagles. I left them 225 with Connell for that purpose. I likewise called at Matthew Cary’s, and told him of the packet from Mr Colburn that I have for him, and of König’s proposals for making his new printing presses. I found Mr Cary not disposed to encourage the views of either of those persons, but he gave me the Supplement to the eighth Edition of his own Olive-Branch— We had visitors at our lodgings until the moment of our departure. Mr and Mrs Ewing. Chandler Price who came with Connell, J. Vaughan, General S. Smith of Baltimore, Mr Willing whom we knew at St. Petersburg, and some others. Willing and Connell, came with us, and saw us on board the Steam-Boat, which was the Delaware, Captain Whelldin— We left the wharf a few minutes after one, and reached Newcastle at eight in the Evening. 40 Miles. We had the tide, and a very light wind against us, and the Delaware is one of the slowest of the Steam-Boats. J. Sergeant took leave of us at the Boat, and Jos. Hopkinson cross’d it to go at the same time in the other Boat to Burlington where he now resides. We found as fellow passengers on board the Boat, Mrs Pascal Smith of New-York, with a Miss Blagge; and a Mr Geyer another of our acquaintance at St. Petersburg. There were also a Mr Birckhead of Baltimore with his wife and a beautiful Sister, and two Frenchmen lately from the Island of Martinique and speaking only French. The day and Evening were remarkably fine. We took lodgings for the Night at the Inn at Newcastle— The old one which I formerly frequented, and now kept by a man named Jackson— We dined in the Boat.

19. IV: Immediately after rising, we proceeded, with the other Steam-Boat travellers in five Stages to Frenchtown. 16 Miles and a very good road. We arrived before eight and immediately embarked in the Steam-Boat Chesapeake Captain Owens. There is another Boat in the same line, the Philadelphia, Captain Trippe, said to be swifter, and in other respects better, but we were perfectly well accommodated in this. The day was as fine as possible, with the tide all day in our favour, and wind barely enough to freshen the air. The deck was covered with an awning as a shelter from the Sun, and while with the tremulous and scarcely perceptible Steam-Boat motion, we were descending Elk river and Chesapeake Bay at the rate of seven and eight-miles an hour, I was viewing the Country as we passed, and reading Colden’s life of his friend Fulton. We Breakfasted and dined in the Boat, and
I finished Colden’s book, just after we came in sight of Baltimore. It was five in the afternoon, when we arrived, and before leaving the Boat we saw Mr Saml. Sterrett who came to receive Mrs P. Smithhis late wife’s Sister and Mr Lloyd Buchanan— Walking from the Boat to Gadsby’s Hotel, the Indian Queen formerly kept by Evans, where we took lodgings for the Night, we met Munroe, the Printer of a Newspaper, whom I had met at the public dinner at Boston; but we were not disturbed this Evening by any visitors. We finish here for the present our Steam-Boat Navigation, which for the purpose of travel far surpasses my highest expectations— I engaged passages in the Stage for Washington to-morrow Morning.

20. V: Washington— We departed from the Indian Queen Tavern at Baltimore, at six O’Clock this Morning; in the Stage; with three fellow travellers unknown to us. Breakfasted at M’Coy’s formerly Spurrier’s, twelve Miles from Baltimore and arrived at Mr Frye’s house in Washington-City at four in the afternoon— Mr Frye has lately married my wife’sSister, the widow Buchanan, and they invited us to stay at their house, until we can go into that which has been taken for us by G. Boyd— After dinner we went first to W. S. Smith’s. He lost yesterday his second child, a daughter 19 months old. They had already lost the first which was born at St. Petersburg. We had found Mr Frye just returned from the funeral of this second child— I then went to Mr Rush’s lodgings at O’Neal’s tavern; but he was not there—then to Mr Boyd’s house, but he was gone to meet his wife at Smith’s— I returned there, and found with Mr and Mrs Boyd, Mrs Hellen, once Adelaide Johnson, my wife’s youngest Sister, and now the widow of my old friend Hellen, whom in March 1809. I had left here the husband of her eldest Sister— Mrs Smith, distressed by the loss of her child was confined to her chamber and I did not see her. I returned with my wife and Mrs Greentree to Mr Frye’s. Mr Rush had already been there to find me. He soon after came and requested me to go with him to the President’s which I did— The President, James Monroe, returned last Wednesday from a tour of nearly four Months to the Eastern and Western parts of the United States. He is in the President’s House, which is so far restored from the effects of the British visit in 1814. that it is now for the first time again inhabitable. But he is apprehensive of the effects of the fresh painting and plaistering, and very desirous of visiting his family at his Seat in Virginia— He is therefore going again to leave the City in two or three days, but said his absence would be only for a short time. He told me that Mr Rush was to be my Successor at the Court of Great: Britain, and directed me to make out Instructions for him— He also entered largely upon the motives of the Mission which he had contemplated sending to South-America, which has however failed for the present; and upon which he said he should converse further with me, before his departure. After some general conversation upon the state of the public Relations with Great-Britain, Spain and France; I left him and returned to Mr Frye’s. Mr Rush gave me some account of the present situation of the Department of State; a subject to be hereafter resumed.
21. V:30. Sunday.

lg.l: Oh! God, my only trust w[as]t thou,
Lo! at thy Throne again I bow,
Thy aid, Oh! Father, wilt thou lend?
My heart, to do thy pleasure, bend?
Grant, for my feeble, faltering will,
Grant active powers, grant fervid zeal;
And ever be my Country’s weal
Thine be the purpose; thine the deed,
From thee all perfect gifts proceed;
And make, to bless my native Land,

div.p:
these lines, dictated by the new situation upon which I am about to enter, served me for the devotions of the day. At the Church where Mr Frye usually attends there was this day no public service, and I accidentally missed attending at any other— W. S. Smith and D. P. Cooke were here in the course of the
morning. The heat of the Sun was so intense—that it confined me all day to the house. I employed it in writing. After bringing up this journal to this day, I also brought up to the present time my account of family expenditures, and wrote a Letter to my Mother. After Sunset I walked out, and meeting Mr Frye walked with him to Mr Boyd’s. Saw there his four Sons, John, Thomas, Joshua, and George— Boyd & his wife were in the mean time gone to Frye’s, where we found them and Mrs Hellen, upon our return. From the information given me by Boyd, the path before me is beset with thorns, and it becomes more doubtful than ever whether I shall be able to continue long in it— At two distinct periods of my life heretofore my position has been perilous, and full of anxious forecasts but never so critical and precarious as at this time.

22. VI:Mr Rush called upon me this Morning immediately after breakfast, and accompanied me to the Office of the Department of State, where the official Oath, faithfully to execute the trust committed to me, prescribed by the act of Congress, establishing the Department of foreign Affairs, and the Oath to support the Constitution of the U. States were administered to me by Robert Brent a Justice of the Peace for the District of Columbia— The appointment of Chief Clerk in the Department has been vacant since the 4th. of March, by the resignation of Mr Graham. But the temporary appointment had been made of Daniel Brent who has been many years in the Office; and who was strongly recommended by the President, and Mr Rush— The other Clerks in the Office,Purviance,King, Richard Forrest and Moses Young, were introduced to me, and I confirmed them all in their respective Offices. I gave Brent the appointment of Chief Clerk— There were a multitude of Letters and despatches which have been laying for me some time on the table of the Office, and the Mail of the day brought many others— I had not time to read them all— I received from Mr Rush and Mr Brent some information with regard to the transaction of business at the Office— Brent says it is much in arrear, but without any accumulation of it since Mr Rush has been at the head of the Department— The Office hours are from nine in the morning to three in the afternoon. Mr Rush mentioned to me several affairs upon which the President, who left Town this morning for Virginia desired me to proceed immediately to business— There were in the course of the Morning several visitors at the Office—W. Lee. C. Cutts. S. Pleasanton, J. L. Cathcart &c— I came home about four O’Clock, and after dinner was writing most of the Evening. R. Rush, and R. Harrison were here. Mr Bagot the British Minister, and Mr Crawford Antrobus the Secretary of Legation, Mr Hyde de Neuville the French Minister, and Mr Roth his Secretary of Legation had left Cards this morning. Mrs. Bagot also visited Mrs Adams.

23. IV:30. Began the morning by making a draft of a Letter to Hyde de Neuville, in answer to a communication from him to the Department of State, concerning a project for invading Mexico from the United States, and declaring Joseph Buonaparte king of Spain and the Indies. B. Homans. Chief Clerk in the Navy Department called on me, and walked part of the way with me to the Office, where I was from ten to three. Many visitors at the Office; and chiefly to solicit Office— D. P. Cook—for himself. My old friend Jos. Anderson, now Comptroller of the Treasury, for his Son. W. S. Smith is now a Clerk in his Office, in a place which he wants for his Son; and with some circumlocution, and some talk about his son’s declining to be a candidate for the Office of Chief Clerk in the Department of State, which he the father had written to me to Quincy, asking me to reserve it for a friend of his, meaning his Son, he now gave me to understand that I must either take his Son, or W. S. Smith as a Clerk in my Office, as otherwise he should remove W. S. Smith from the place he now holds to put his Son into it. I told him that I could take no family relation of my own into my Office, nor recommend any one to another Department. I had appointed Mr Brent Chief Clerk; because he was already in the Office; because he was recommended by the President and Mr Rush, and because there was no ground for me to remove him. I considered myself under an obligation to appoint another person to the place vacated by Mr Brent— He asked if it was either of the Clerks now in the office. I said no. He said there was another Clerkship in the Department, vacated by Mr Pleasonton, to which
the President wished that his brother might be appointed; but had felt some delicacy about speaking of it to me— Here the matter rested; but Anderson determined to remove Smith and give the place to his Son. I spoke to him also about de Grand’s affair, and he said he had written about it to the District Attorney at Boston. He told me that Mr Crawford the Secretary of the Treasury had arrived in town last Evening. W. Lee came to ask a place in the Office for the Son of Mr Fenwick formerly Consul at Bordeaux. I received also a Letter from a person named Grouard, with a certificate from Gales one of the Editors of the National Intelligencer— A Lieutenant Osgood brought me a Letter from Dr. Waterhouse— Brent brought me the Letters lately received from Mr Gallatin at Paris, and Mr Pinkney at St. Petersburg. I had much conversation with Mr Rush on the answers to be returned to the French and Spanish Ministers, and with him visited Mr Hyde de Neuville— Came home in the rain— We had an evening family party and supper at W. S. Smith’s.

24. IV:30. Drafted this morning before breakfast an answer to two Letters from the Spanish Minister. At the office from ten to four O’Clock; but the Papers to read, and the visitors absorb the Office hours so that I find there scarcely a moment for writing. I made out however a circular notification to the foreign Ministers accredited here that I had taken upon me the duties of Secretary of State. Sent my letter to the French Minister— Mr Brent informed me that Mr Rush wished for a definitive Order from the President, for him to take passage, in the Franklin 74 Gun Ship— I intimated to Rush himself a doubt whether some inconvenience to himself might not result from the impression, which might be made by his going in that vessel; but he had set his heart upon going in her, and anticipated rather with exultation the impression that it would make in England. I promised therefore to write to the President on the subject. Returning from the Office I paid a visit to Mr Bagot— In the Evening we had visits from Mr Breckenridge, Dr Thornton, Mr M’Kean and D. P. Cook— The weather has at length become supportable.

25. V: Wrote a Letter to the President of the United States. Visits from MrT. T. Tucker, the Treasurer, and from Saml. H. Smith, Commissioner of the Public Revenue. It was eleven before I reached the Office. Visits from Genl. John Mason; from MrCrawford, Secretary of the Treasury, from Mr Elliot a Chaplain in the army; and formerly while I was in the Senate, chaplain to Congress, and from W. Lee. Crawford again renewed the proposal for me to take young Anderson into the State Department, that there may be room for W. S. Smith in the place he now holds in the Comptroller’s Office. I repeated that it was impossible. Mr Rush gave me a minute of Instructions to be made out for Mr Prevost. Lee came to make some disclosures about the project for invading Mexico; but they amounted to little. He hoped to have more to say to-morrow— Evening visit from R. Forrest, and D. P. Cook— Mrs Hellen here— I received from the French Minister a reply to my Letter of yesterday.

26. IV: From which hour till breakfast time, I was engaged in writing Letters. On my way to the Office, I returned the visit of Mr Baker, the British Consul General, who was the Secretary to the British Plenipotentiaries at Ghent— He was engaged and I left a Card. Mr Clay called upon me at the Office. Mr Bagot the British Minister had by a Note yesterday asked an interview with me, for which I had appointed this day at 2. O’Clock— This Morning Mr Hyde de Neuville sent a note saying that he found himself obliged to leave the City sooner than he had expected, and requesting an interview, which I gave him immediately. We had a long Conversation of which as well as of all others it is henceforth utterly impossible for me to keep any record. It gave me however some insight into his character— Mr Bagot came at two, and had also with me a Conversation of about half an hour. Mr De Neuville’s views changed so much in the course of our Conference from what they had been by his Letter of last Evening, as made it necessary for me to consult with Mr Rush; and to write to the President. After dinner I took a walk to Georgetown, as far as the Catholic Church. In the Evening after I returned, I prepared from Rush’s minutes, Instructions for J. B. Prevost, and began a Letter to the President. But even in less than one week since I entered upon my Office, I find my eyes already so much affected that before ten I was obliged to desist from writing and retire to repose.

27. V:30. At dawn of day. Since Monday I have until this morning written an hour or two by Candle-light before day. This morning I rose later. In the Winter I shall be forced to write by candle-light— I hope it will be also possible. Wrote a Letter to the President, and prepared from Rush’s minutes, Instructions for J. B. Prevost— At the Office I had personal applications from R. Smith and from Mr M’Cormick, a Clergyman for a Clerkship in the Department. Opened a trunk of the Books brought with me from England. Called at the Office of Mr George Graham, acting Secretary at War, but he was not there— Went to the Treasury Office, and saw Mr Crawford, Mr Anderson, and Mr Pleasonton— W. Lee and General Van Darmine were with Mr Crawford when I first went to him; but he had heard nothing of the project for conquering Mexico, or for making Joseph Buonaparte king of Spain and the Indies till I told him. I spoke to him
and to Mr Anderson about De Grand’s affair— They told me it was agreed that the suit against him should be dismissed; and as to the question about the costs that no instructions would be given. I gave Mr Pleasonton a copy of the missing number of my Accounts, and all the vouchers that I had collected— The instructions for J. B. Prevost were not sent, a suggestion being made to me by Mr Brent, that Captain Biddle might expect to be associated with Prevost in the execution of part of his business— It was half past four when I came home to dinner— Before dark, I went with my wife and called upon Mrs Hellen. W. S. Smith and his wife were there. We returned early, D. P. Cook spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s.

28. IV: I waked between two and three with the tooth-ache, which has for several days been troublesome to me. I lay an hour or more, without being able to sleep again and then rose to write Letters. Was employed all the morning in writing to J. T. Austin, and answering a Letter yesterday received from A. H. Everett. W. Lee came and read me an account drawn up by him of all the information obtained by him from the french exiles and projectors here. He is to make out another copy to be sent to the President to-morrow. Received visits from Genl. Parker, Mrs Boyd &c— I went to Mr Rush to consult him respecting the Instructions to Prevost, and the Letter to J. T. Austin— Met Decatur at Rush’s. After dinner, went with my wife and Mr and Mrs Frye to St. John’s Church and heard Mr Wilmer preach from Psalm VIII.4. [“]Lord what is man that thou art mindful of him; and the Son of man that thou visitest him.” The Sermon as well as the text was taken from Chalmers and avowed. After Church we went to tea and passed the Evening at Mrs Hellen’s where we met Mr and Mrs Boyd, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith and Mr Jos. Forrest— Mr Brent called upon me this morning and told me his house, which I have taken for a year would be ready to receive our effects to-morrow. The Messenger of the Department brought the Mail to me at Mr Frye’s.

29. IV:30. My wife was unwell in the Night. I was again waked about three and could not afterwards sleep. Wrote to the President. Had a visit from Mr George Graham, acting Secretary at War with Mrthe third Auditor. I called at the Treasury Office, and consulted with Mr Crawford, who agreed with me that Captain Biddle should be associated with J. B. Prevost in the authority to take territorial possession at the mouth of Columbia river. He told me that Mr Clay did not believe in these levies of men in the Western States by French emigrants, and that he was determined at the next Session of Congress to propose the acknowledgment of the South American Insurgents. Mr Crawford said he had advised the Mission to South-America, and seemed dissatisfied that the Commissioners were not yet gone. He said it would now be too late for the object intended which was to obtain full information before the Meeting of Congress. W. Lee came with a copy of his Statement which I forwarded to the President— I dined with my wife at Mr Bagot’s. The company were Mr Clay, Commodore and Mrs Decatur, Genl. and Mrs Mason and their Son, Mr Brent. Mr Baker the British Consul General and his brother, and Mr Hughes, Mr Bagot’s private Secretary. The Secretary of Legation Mr Antrobus was not there. We came home about eight in the Evening.

30. IV. Waked again at three O’Clock by the tooth ache, and rose at four. Wrote to the President and to my brother. At the Office I was less interrupted by visitors than any former day and spent the Morning in reading over the despatches of G. W. Erving and T. Pinkney, Mr Rush called and I had much Conversation with him in relation to the prospects of his mission to England— After dinner I took a walk of an hour with Mr Frye— The removal of our furniture and effects to the house which we are to occupy was this day commenced. In the Evening I wrote two Letters—to C. J. Ingersoll and J. Lathrop.

Day. The first third part of the Month, was passed at Boston and Quincy, like the preceding fortnight. The second third on the Journey to this place, and the remainder at the house of my wife’s sister Mrs Frye and at the Office of the Department of State. Through the Month I have invariably risen before six in the Morning, and here usually between four and five— I am yet to be regularly settled, at my house and in the routine of Office— I am to pray for health, industry, perseverance and wisdom from above.
